TB Information

What is TB?

TB is short for Tuberculosis, a bacterial infection caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Active TB targets the lungs and was once a major cause of death in the United States.  Although much has been done to control the spread of TB today it can still be deadly if not treated properly. With current medical treatments active TB (TB with present symptoms) can be cured and latent (dormant) TB can be treated to prevent it from developing into active TB.

How is TB transmitted?

TB is transmitted person to person through tiny air droplets. Someone with active TB spreads TB by coughing, sneezing, speaking, or singing when others are nearby.

People with active TB will most likely transmit the infection to people they spend the most time with: family members, coworkers, roommates, and friends.

Symptoms:

People with active TB have the following symptoms:

  • Body Aches
  • Fever
  • Weight Loss
  • Night Sweats
  • Chills
  • Loss of Appetite
  • Fatigue
  • Coughing Blood
  • "Bad cough" that lasts more than 3 weeks

Latent TB has no active symptoms and cannot be detected without a test.

Who needs to have a TB test?

The Church has now specified every mission, stateside and foreign, to be high risk for TB because of the high volume of international missionaries and the diversity of people they encounter.  All missionaries upon returning from the mission need to have a TB test.

Also those who have lived or traveled to high risk countries need to have a new TB test upon return.

If you have answered YES to any of the TB questionnaire questions you will need to take a TB test.

What if I have had the BCG vaccine?

Just because you have received a TB vaccine called BCG it doesn't mean you are automatically immune. There is still a chance you can get TB.  If you have been given the BGC vaccine you DO NOT need a TB skin test but you DO need a TB blood test. This is called a T-Spot test.

What if I have tested positive for TB?

If you have had a positive PPD test and then a positive t-spot you will never have to do another t-spot test. If someone requires you to be tested for TB you will notify them that you have tested positive with the blood test. You will then have a chest x-ray done.

TB Testing at BYU-Idaho:

At BYU-Idaho, students at risk for TB are tested in the following order:

  1. A skin test (Mantoux test) is performed, where a small amount of fluid (tuberculin or PPD) is injected under the skin on the arm and then the site is observed for signs of reaction after 48-72 hours.
  2. If the skin test is positive, then the student has a blood test done called T-spot. This test is done by drawing a small amount of blood and then checking the blood sample for antibodies that would indicate the presence of the TB bacteria in the body.
  3. If the T-spot test is positive then the student will meet with a Doctor at the Student Health Center to evaluate the condition and then have a chest x-ray to find evidence of active TB. From this point on, the student will receive the appropriate treatment for latent TB.
